awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Collaborative Research: Strengthen the Foundation of Big Data Analytics via Interdisciplinary Research among HBCUs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will be implemented by an interdisciplinary research team from two neighboring historical Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU) and Texas Southern University (TSU), with the goals of strengthening the theoretical foundation of big data analytics and developing a novel deep learning software package based on this enhanced foundation. Challenges around big data impacts many areas and encourages exciting further investigation to understand the complex requirements of real-world applications. 

Specifically, this team aims to 1) improve the understanding and explainability of deep neural networks with the quantum theory of modern physics; 2) enhance the mathematical foundation of deep neural networks; 3) increase the computation efficiency of the deep learning training process with new algorithms that will scale; and 4) implement the deep learning research innovations into a new deep learning software package to deploy in cloud computing and High-Performance Computing platforms.

This project will aid the research in a wide range of areas of applications, from academic studies to the oil and gas industry and the military by offering deep learning models and improved computational efficiency and scalability. Students will benefit from the opportunity to contribute to the forefront of science research and technology. The project will broaden participation by opening stimulating research opportunities to a diverse group of underrepresented minority students. The two campuses and the members of the interdisciplinary team complement each other; by exchanging and sharing expertise and students the collaboration therefore has a beneficial and synergistic effect on multiple levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of the collaborative research project was to strengthen the theoretical foundation of big data analytics and to build a novel deep learning software package to facilitate research and education in both data science and computation. The completed project was well aligned with the missions of Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU) and Texas Southern University (TSU), two neighboring Historical Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), in building the data science and computation research capacity, enriching the learning environment, and stimulating students' interest in STEM at the undergraduate and graduate level, especially to the underrepresented groups. In the first four years of the project, the work on Scientific Machine Learning was applied to fluid dynamics simulations, molecular dynamics simulations and pharmacokinetics/pharmacodynamics modeling, which expose us to new needs for theoretical and applications of deep neural networks. In the fifth year of the project, the new PI focused on applications of Machine Learning on computational biology and cybersecurity domains. The main outcomes of the project can be categorized as the following:

 Research: The project achieved significant outcomes in advancing the enhancement and the efficiency of deep neural networks. Researchers from both HBCU institutions devised methodologies, implemented algorithms, and developed software to integrate established agnostic deep learning techniques with constraints derived from the physics applications. These applications included distinguishing seismic activity as natural or anthropogenic and detecting neurological diseases through electroencephalogram (EEG) signals. Additionally, this project paved the way to further understand the applications of Machine Learning (ML) in the life sciences domain. DNA methylations effects were examined utilizing traditional bioinformatics pipelines in conjunction with ML tools. DNA methylation (DNAm) is the most common regulatory modification that affects gene expression, splicing, and other important genomic aspects such as chromatin structure and transgenerational transmission stability. The volume of NGS-generated data demands a multidisciplinary team with various skills to derive meaningful interpretation of the underlying conditions. With the support of this award, students learned the necessary background knowledge to understand these complex biological processes and make sense of large volume of data generated by modern sequencing machines. Multiple peer-reviewed papers were published in journals and conferences to present our results to the scientific community.

 Students training: Project sponsored the ML education of the undergraduate and graduate students with the goal of preparing under-represented PVAMU undergraduate and graduate students for the challenges of data analytics and preparing them for a career in data science and research. Through the course of the project, each student started by learning about basic data science tools and techniques such as programming in R and Python languages, Shell and version control concepts. The publicly available resources such as Software Carpentry Lessons were employed in training. Students also learned about High Performance Computing (HPC) concepts and granted access to Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC) to conduct research in a cloud computing environment.

 Annual joint workshops and student organization: throughout the project, TSU and PVAMU held three annual workshops, which were well-received. As the nature of the research was data science and thus multi-disciplinary, the team reached out to internal researchers and students at PVAMU and established internal collaborations. Furthermore, the PVAMU student data science club benefited from this project through educational activities.

 Developed Training material for Data science: Our education goal was to expose and encourage more students from underrepresented minorities to data science. To achieve this goal, we recruited students, who mostly didn’t have any experience in basic data analysis/science skills or computational biology. After the first few weeks, they were able to grasp the basic concepts as well as the mathematical concepts behind the machine learning tools. At the end of the program, they were able to handle end-to-end data science projects and present their results to a general audience. We have installed machine learning software tools (such as: SciKit-learn, TensorFlow, Keras, Pytorch) in the cloud computing facility at PSC and the student computers. Our results were presented at nationally reputable conferences and our research facilitated the way for a follow up grant funded by the Air Force Office of Scientific Research in collaborations with TSU, Texas A&M University and Michigan State University.

 Curriculum development.  The enhancement of the current courses and proposing new courses were an important part of the project. We have enhanced the content of the COMP 3311, Introduction to Data Science course, offered by the Department of Computer Science at PVAMU. Additionally, the material for the COMP 4316, Machine Learning, course will be improved to reflect the findings of the project.

 New Grant.  The current NSF grant empowered collaboration between TSU and PVAMU and paved the way to future collaborations. Our research facilitated the way for a follow up grant funded by the Air Force Office of Scientific Research in collaboration with TSU, Texas A&M University and Michigan State Universit
